title: Diploma in Firestore Development
headline: Learn how to develop stylish interactive apps for iOS and Android using Firestore technology in this free online course.
description: This free online Firestone development diploma course will teach you about how you can enhance your development abilities with Firestore. You will learn how to create and save data to your Firestore database as well as create and customise stylish interactive features such as text fields, buttons, and menu options. You will also cover topics such as Creating User VC, Setting Up User ID, Logging In and Out, and more!

courseDescription:
In this video-based course you will learn how to develop an app for the iOS and Android platforms, using Firestore real-time database. In the process of building the app, you will learn all about Firestore. You will learn how to set up a Firestore project, how to create and save data to your database and how to retrieve and sort the data as needed. By the end of this course, you will have a strong understanding of the fundamentals of Firestore and how it can be used to create an app.

Firestore is a flexible, scalable database for mobile, web and sever development. It is available from Firestore and the Google Cloud platform. Like the Firebase real-time database, it keeps your data in sync across client apps, through real-time "listeners" and offers offline support. You will learn how to use programming code effectively for iOS and Android platforms. You will use mockup designs to customise your app. You will learn how to configure text boxes, buttons, alert boxes and menu options, to create stylish interactive features. You will learn how to develop an app where users can publish posts, add comments and receive 'likes'. Moreoever, you will understand how these features interact with Firestore through data, documents and collections.

If you're interested in app development as a career, or if you're a professional programmer seeking to learn new skills, then this course is the one for you. By following the video-based instruction, supplementing the demonstrations with further research and by practicing, you will, in a relatively short time have the knowledge and skills to create a functional app that can be used for a variety of purposes. So start this course today, and by the end of the week youâ€™ll have gained valuable new skills for app development.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our diploma pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Creating an iOS App in Firestore
modules.description: This module introduces iOS app development in Firestore and covers topics such as Setting up a Project; About Firestore; Developing the User Interface; Adding Data to the Database; Main VC U Setup; Fetching Data from Firestore; Sorting and Filtering; Updating Documents.
topics: Creating an iOS App in Firestore - Learning Outcomes
Creating an App in Firestore - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module introduces you to features in an app and covers topics such as Log In/Create User VC; Setting Up User ID; Logging In and Out; Comments Setup; Comments Configuration; Comments and Transactions; Displaying Comments; Setting Security Rules.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module covers using an app and introduces you to topics such as Adding an Options Menu; Tap Gesture Recogniser; Deleting a Comment; Edit Comments; Advanced Comments Security; Deleting Thoughts; Deleting Thoughts and Comments; Summary and Task.

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Firestore Development - First Assessment
modules.description: You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment. You can repeat this assessment to pass it.
topics: Diploma in Firestone Development - First Assessment

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Firestore and Android - App Project Setup
modules.description: This modules cover topics such as Android App Project Setup; Post View UI; Database Connection; Main Page Categories; Thoughts Adaptor; Data Fetching; Real-time Updates; Adding Likes.
topics: Firestore and Android - App Project Setup - Learning Outcomes
Firestore and Android - App Project Setup - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Firestore and Android - User Login and Authentication
modules.description: In this module you will review Firestone for Android in more detail and it covers topics such as Login/Create User Screens; User Authentication; Options Menu; Adding Comments; Comments Adaptor; Displaying Comments; Security Rules.
topics: Firestore and Android - User Login and Authentication - Learning Outcomes
Firestore and Android - User Login and Authentication - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Firestore and Android - Managing Your Project
modules.description: In this module you'll learn about Project Setup in Firestone; Interfaces; Deleting a Comment; Updating a Comment; Comments Security; Deleting Thoughts and Comments; Thought Security Rules; Overview and Tasks.
topics: Firestore and Android - Managing Your Project - Learning Outcomes
Firestore and Android - Managing Your Project - Lesson Summary

• Module One Lesson Summary

    • Firestore is a flexible, scalable database for mobile, web and sever development.  It is available for iOS, Android and Web and from Firestore and the Google Cloud platform.
    • Like the Firebase real-time database, Firestore keeps your data in synch across client apps, through real-time "listeners" and offers offline support for mobile and web.
    • One of the biggest differences between Firestore and Firebase, is how data is organised. In Firestore, data is organised in collections and documents. 
    • An app, based on Firestore no-SQL document technology was built. The concept behind the app, is a place where people can share their random thoughts about the world. You can sort by various topics, "like" different posts and add your own. 
    • You learned how to set up a Firestore project, how to create and save data to a database and retrieve and sort the data as needed. 
    • You were shown how a new project is created in Firestore, as well as how to access Google's Firebase repository.
    • Downloading the Google service P-list was shown, as well as using 'cocoapods' as an add-on.
    • Each Firestore collection contains one or more documents and each document is made up of key value pairs, which are referred to as "fields".

• Module One Lesson Summary

    • One of the biggest differences between Firestore and Firebase, is how data is organised. In Firestore, data is organised in collections and documents. 
    • An app, based on Firestore no-SQL document technology was built. The concept behind the app, is a place where people can share their random thoughts about the world. You can sort by various topics, "like" different posts and add your own. 
    • You learned how to set up a Firestore project, how to create and save data to a database and retrieve and sort the data as needed. 
    • You were shown how a new project is created in Firestore, as well as how to access Google's Firebase repository.
    • Downloading the Google service P-list was shown, as well as using 'cocoapods' as an add-on.
    • Each Firestore collection contains one or more documents and each document is made up of key value pairs, which are referred to as "fields".

• Module Two Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Develop log in and create user features for an app
    • Develop secure user authentication
    • Adapt app functionality based on authentication
    • Create a comments feature for an app
    • Use xcode to customise a Comments UI 
    • Explain Firestore transactions
    • Discuss how listeners and snapshots are used
    • Apply security rules in Firestore

• Setting Security Rules

  • In this lesson, security rules are discussed and applied for authenticated users and user documents and a summary of what was covered in the module is given.

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Module Two Lesson Summary

    • In this module, a View Controller (VC) was developed for user login and to create a new user. Buttons and text fields were customised with a font, background, colours and borders. Constraints were set to position the elements.
    • User authentication was developed using cocoapods and the Firebase SDK system. Setting up user authentication in xcode, involves obtaining the user's credentials, i.e. username and password and verification.
    • An 'auth' protocol was used to assign user access.
    • The status of users needs to be tracked in the app. A listener needs to be set, to determine if the user is logged in or not and how the app should function. 
    • A comments feature was added to the app - a speech bubble, with the number of comments shown and the ability to add a comment. When the bubble is clicked, it displays the comments, together with the date, time and username.
    • When a comment is added, the field value for the "thought" is updated. When someone clicks on the 'add comment' button, a transaction is run. 
    • Transactions are used in instances of multiple read and writes. The data is updated using the number of comments field, i.e. it is incremented by one.
    • The ordering of the comments was initially incorrect. 'Order by string' code was added to the CommentsVC file, which corrected the error.

• Module Two Lesson Summary

    • In this module, a View Controller (VC) was developed for user login and to create a new user. Buttons and text fields were customised with a font, background, colours and borders. Constraints were set to position the elements.
    • User authentication was developed using cocoapods and the Firebase SDK system. Setting up user authentication in xcode, involves obtaining the user's credentials, i.e. username and password and verification.
    • An 'auth' protocol was used to assign user access.
    • The status of users needs to be tracked in the app. A listener needs to be set, to determine if the user is logged in or not and how the app should function. 
    • A comments feature was added to the app - a speech bubble, with the number of comments shown and the ability to add a comment. When the bubble is clicked, it displays the comments, together with the date, time and username.
    • When a comment is added, the field value for the "thought" is updated. When someone clicks on the 'add comment' button, a transaction is run. 
    • Transactions are used in instances of multiple read and writes. The data is updated using the number of comments field, i.e. it is incremented by one.
    • The ordering of the comments was initially incorrect. 'Order by string' code was added to the CommentsVC file, which corrected the error.

• Module Three Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Develop an options menu to edit and delete posts
    • Explain how a gesture recogniser is used
    • Update the number of comments following deletion
    • Summarise how a segue or connection is made in xcode
    • Develop user specific security rules
    • Use code from Cloud Firestore to delete collections
    • Customise the project app or create a new one

    • Update the number of comments following deletion
    • Summarise how a segue or connection is made in xcode
    • Develop user specific security rules
    • Use code from Cloud Firestore to delete collections
    • Customise the project app or create a new one

• Module Three Lesson Summary

    • App features that remained to be developed included: editing and deleting posts and comments and adding a special icon next to content produced by the logged-in user. 
    • The course resource files include different styles of icons that can be used. 
    • Learners were shown how to delete test documents in their database. 
    • The tap gesture recogniser was configured for the options menu, so that the menu appears next to the relevant user. The image was made "user interactable". 
    • When the options menu is tapped, the gesture recogniser picks it up and calls the selector function. 
    • When the program is run, the menu option appears next to the logged in user's posts. 
    • The functionality for deleting comments was implemented. 
    • Functions in the alert box include actions for editing, deleting and cancelling. 
    • Code was added to the CommentsVC file, to enable the delete function.
    • The number of comments does not initially update following a deletion. Transaction code is used to fix this. The number of comments is changed from +1 to -1.
    • A new VC was created, with a text field for editing a comment, including an update button. 
    • A segue or connection was made between the CommentsVC and the new VC, using the click and drag method.
